reviewText:
Early Access Review

To start off with, this game is not worth $25 for the amount of content that was released. I participated in the Pre-Alpha/Beta Testing and believe they need more time to get the basics down before they shipped if off to EA.

I have a long history with playing shooters and started off with S1-S4(including CON) and I have to say that we are playing games in 2015 and I would like to see a tactical third person shooter where its realism is believable. Right now, they are not where they need to be.

This game is suppose to be a soul successor of the famous title Socom Us Navy Seals, but falls short with many many fundamental problems.

I wouldnt recommend you to pick up this game till maybe about 3-4 months down the road, where I can see the Devs picking up their act and implementing a competitive side to the game.

Details:

Character/movement - The Characters you control are very robotic, very little sway or any fluid movement, when controlling the gun you dont see or feel like your receiving any kick back from the gun. its like the gun was mounted on a rock that can have the ability to move around. Jumping around feels like your on the moon, being able to shoot as if you were standing still or your running through the air. lots of things that your character will get stuck on, like pivots in the ground, rubble that should be easily cleared, or inclined terrain that anyone can walk up on. Your Character doesnt seem to have any inertia, or body weight when moving around and can change direction(strafe or back pedal) on a drop of a dime with no transfer of weight being displayed. your back pedal is the same speed as if you run forward. you cant dive properly and with many bugs with Dolphin Pop Up Animation exploits(sliding off the ground being able to shoot accurately and still be mobile).

Characters dont feel like they receive damage from anything. Bullets, Pellets, Grenades, or Fall Damage. Character does not slow down when receiving damage untill dead.

Movement Speed is way too fast and arcady to believe you are playing a human character with combat gear and weapons.

There is no Sprint button, You either Press a button to walk, or you move around at a run/jog speed in all directions. No Ability to put your gun down to sacrifice for top flight speed.

Gunplay - The Aiming system is One Dimensional which is point and shoot, There is no general aim or focused aim. There are scopes for the Snipers, but if you have to make a long range shot with a AR or SMG, you will have to scope in with your binocular zoom out and shoot in the regular point and click Classic View). There is no depth in the shooting mechanics, you are set in a battle stance that you are shooting as if you are looking down the sights of the gun all the time(and still are able to move around at jog-running speed in all directions)

- Stances play no role in how you control your gun. Same bullet pattern, same spread.

-All guns pretty much do the same damage, have the same kind of bullet spray, and dont have any feel.
- Fire Rates and How many bullets the gun has really makes the difference in the game.

-Holding down the trigger will only kick your spray pattern so much till it stops at the top of the cross-hair circle. And it will automaticly return to the original point where you started shooting.

Sub Machine Guns can out snipe any gun class. If you want a challenge use the Assault Rifles or Sniper and feel the struggle.

Pistols suffer from bullet delay and do very little damage.(Desert Eagle is the pistol of choice because of its different damage)

Shotguns are never used because its DMG is based off of how many pellets make contact, and there are no knock downs or staggering effects when hitting your enemy.

Grenades/Throwables - You can only throw at Max Distance or Min Distance. You cannot control or gauge the throw. When changing directions from straight to left or right while throwing makes the item go 90 degrees to that direction.

Excessive Bullet Travel - Long Range I think its fine, but the close range combat feels like if you shoot at a wall or target from 3 feet away from you, the bullet is lagging behind your character and will hit 1 foot behind while you mov at a constant speed in 1 direction.

Game rewards spraying more than burst fire(due to fundamental problems^^^^).

No Mic Support

In game Text is displayed for everyone that is playing in your room(dead or alive).

You have to keep picking your gear at the start of every round.(does not remember your previous load out)

2 maps only

1 game mode set to each map.

Incomplete Features for Demolition Game Mode.
-Bomb Location in game
-Which Team has the bomb
-Which Team dropped the bomb
-Many glitches in planting the bomb(locks up character, fail to plant bomb and cannot repick it up, cannot cancel a plant and more.)

Doors are inconsistent

Sound in game is terrible, cannot figure out where shots are being fired from, where people are walking.

So.... probably way more problems but I do not see this game developing faster than what we have seen to Pre EA, if we do they still need more time to fix all the bugs that come with each patch.

I see a lot of inconsistency and I believe its lack of true direction and a big division in the community.

If you want the nostalgia feeling and want to reconnect with a bunch of socom type of player go for it, but get ready for a rough ride with this game.

Update: as of August 7th, 2015

The game still isn't worth $25....BUT it has improved.

- There is a new map called Factory and it is so much better than the original two maps. I actually had a lot of fun playing Factory.

- I have came to the conclusion that the original maps are just bad. In all honesty those two maps are so bad I think it took away from my playing experience when the game launched.

- There is now three game modes..TDM, Demo, and Sabatage..IMO they need to tweak sabatage to play more like breach did in Socom (adding breach points, ect, to make the mode more unique) As of now its basically just demo but the SOF side spawns with the bomb and is the only team that can plant it.

- The shooting mechanics are much better than what I played back at launch of EA. I mean night/day difference

- Grenade throwing has been fixed, the nades no longer shoot off in a random direction. They also added smoke nades, which I do not think were in the game before.

- The guns have a more unique feel now than they did before...meaning the shoot, feel, and handle differently from one to the next.

- Sniper rifles still need work and they need to add the one hitter rifles

- Movement animations are still rough, but they have made some improvements, the jumping looks a little better but still needs work.


I will give credit where it is due and in this case they have made some solid improvements. The main reason I say this game is still not worth $25 is because there is only 1 map worth playing (the new factory map). The other two maps are still terrible. If they can get 3-4 solid maps in this game than it might have a chance.

My only other concern is the player count. This is an online only shooter and each time I have logged in I see less than 20 people online. There is usually only one active room. That is a major concern for an online only game and something to take into consideration prior to buying.

Early Access Review

They say this is a spiritual successor to SOCOM 1/2 for the PS2. I must ask, what are they smoking? Have that many people truly forgot what SOCOM 1 and 2 stood for and what they were? To say HHour is anything close to those masterpieces of a game is a insult to thefolks who worked on those original SOCOM games.

Lets get the facts out of the way on who I am writing this review.

I am a:
SOCOM Vet (1 and 2 my favs)
A Kickstarter backer of this project
Someone who actually wants this game to succeed.

Now that is out of the way. This game in no way even delivers to my needs and I am their target audience. I am one of the many original KS investors of this project.

Why should you buy this game?
1) You have some spare money and are extremely desperate for a generic round based third person shooter.
2) You have never played SOCOM 1 or 2 and thus do not know how far off this game is from being even in the same ballpark as those games.

Why you should not buy this game?

1) There is no voice chat in the game at all. No way to be tactical at all with your teammates nor communicate with them.
2) The grenade arc in the game is atrocious and half the time my grenades go 90 degrees to the right of me without any rhyme or reason.
3) I constantly shoot at and get shot by my own teammates because the indicator on their head is not only terrible in distance/range but completely useless after a certain further range. Be prepared to get shot at constantly by your teammates. Friendly fire is not in this game and this is probably why.
4) There is no indicator, icon, map or radar to show who has the bomb in demolition game mode. Have fun knowing trying to play tactically when you have no clue what is going on.
5) WolfRun is one of the worst maps I have ever played in a shooter. It is Socom 4 levels of bad.
6) All of the guns shoot exactly the same. The only difference is their names. The sprays are identical for every gun.
7) The audio is broken and you are unable to tell where shots are coming from. Footsteps are somewhat manageable to hear but also suffer from similar issues. There are no red indicators like Socom had that show the direction of incoming enemy fire.
8) Sloppy animations. I do not mind these too much but some people do.
9) You have to pick your weapon each round even if you want to use the same weapon or if you did not die in the previous round? Anyone who played classic Socom games knows that you did not HAVE to pick the weapon you wanted to use every round, you kept the same gun each round unless you changed it.
10) No PMN mines at all. They were in the Proof of concept yet are not in this paid version. Probably a good thing since there is no voice chat.
11) Zero tactical gameplay at all. I feel like I am playing with bots who camp.
12) The price. This is without a doubt the biggest flaw of this game. This game is in no way worthy of a 25 dollar price tag. I would not even pay 10 dollars for it in its current state and I am a person who backed this project.
13) No stat tracking, no clan support etc. I honestly cannot see this game getting into a competitive gamers heart without these things.
14) Sniping is not even in the same ballpark as Socom games. Just look up some videos to see the difference.
15) 2 maps and 2 game modes.....thats all that is in the game. This is not a typo, your 25 dollars gets you 2 maps 2 game modes....

The game has potential yes, but you could seriously say that about every game on this planet. There are so many flaws in this game right now and it is not worthy of your time nor money as of todays date. Maybe in 6-8 months they will get the product in a state worthy of your time and money but it is not even close to that today. The Socom community deserves more than what this game currently has to offer.

I can not recommend this game in it's current state at all. Sure, the game can be fun at times, but there are too many negative aspects to it.

First of all, the game is running on Unreal Engine 4. Don't get me wrong, graphics aren't the most important thing to me, but they look very dated. If I wouldn't know this runs on UE4, I would assume this runs on Unreal Engine 2.5  (Also the game crashed multiple times with an Unreal Engine 4 fatal error.)

The in game voice chat isn't really helpful. It sounds bad and sometimes it's choppy as well. It often happens that shots don't do any damage or get registered due to the bad hitboxes and hit detection.


The movement / controls feel very stiff as well as the animations. There are not many characters and almost no customisation. There is an okayish amount of weapons. Some more characters, weapons and more customisation would be a nice thing though.

The biggest issue with this game is it's playerbase, it is almost non existant. If you're lucky enough to find people, then only on US servers which isn't that great for european players. Also the small core group that's playing has hundreds of hours in this game, and will give you a hard time as a newbie.


Bottom line:

It's not worth the 15€ price tag. The game has potential, but lacks polish, a vital playerbase and content. If you decide to buy it, then get it while it's heavily discounted.

H-Hour is shaping up to be the best attempt for a foundation of a Classic Third-Person shooter (Socom). If you are okay with a barebones 3rd-Person shooter, this may be for you. In its current state it is playable and can be fun at times with a few friends using a third party communication program. Currently there is no in game mic chat, only text. I want to review this based on what it is and not what it should be or will be down the road. I will update my review as I see fit when things become updated. The Dev team has done a good job tweaking and adding small things since the beta began in April. I was not part of the alpha so I do not know what progress was made then. If you plan on helping a great concept continue to strive towards what fellow Socomers want like I do, by all means, get the early access and help contribute. If you are expecting a polished game with many features found in other Full release games on steam, hold off for at least a few months. Check back regularly and eventually I could see this being a good game. With all issues aside with how the game got to this point, I would recommend it if you want to be in a community that wants to see this game succeed. I would overall not recommend it as I feel the price to value is not something I can support. Speaking to people whom were not fans of Socom I would not purchase this until it is more developed. I personally requested that this be delayed for 8-10 months but obviously it was not.

Pros:

+Game functions as long as you have a decent PC I would say no older than 4 years old equipment.

+It has glimpses of the Socom Feel if you were a fan. If you weren't a fan of socom, it has moments of intensity when you are outnumbered and/or outgunned

+Round Based best of 11.

+Has tie breakers.

+A decent variety of firearms. Rifles, handguns, grenades, flash bangs, and smokes.

+Can be played with a controller or M+K.

+Patches are released on a pretty frequent basis ( 1 per week during the closed beta ) That may be subject to change.

Cons:

-The biggest thing is Lack of Content. 2 maps, 2 game types (elimination and demolition)

-No in game Mics. I use a site called Rabbit for open mic chat.

-Various glitches, nothing that completely ruins the game but you will find them, often. That is the point of Early Access though.

-Lack of overall polish to the gameplay, look and feel.

-Can't switch teams once the game has started.

I myself will play it as I have my Nostalgic Socom goggles on and do like playing it for a little at a time as well as I would like to support it. However I can't recommend this to anyone I know that isn't familiar with Socom. There is just not enough here to warrant $25.

I will write a full review soon.....

Edit: review updated to match the current patch

Let me start by saying that i'm not an old school socom fan, i'm just a third person shooter lover with +50 third person games in the last 5 years on my list both on steam and consoles on my background. So this review is oriented to ppl who couldn't care less about the girls locker room dramas associated with this game and answer one thing: - are you about to buy a good game?

If you're looking for a finished product or you're just a first person shooter kind of guy, the answer is no. There's no competitive third person shooter that can implement first person perspective and done it right, and h-hour is no exception. Even if you enjoy third person games or third person co-op´s, i still don't believe this would be a game that you would enjoy enough to call your money worth as it is right now.

But if you dig games like competitive third person shooters this is definitely a game that you should get. What you're going to find here is really solid mechanics that you can easily pull out +100 hours out of it. If you wanna know why, keep reading.

Gameplay: - What makes the “sockrak” formula so addicting is how the mechanics of the gunfights work. Basically whoever knows how to strife and keep the aim on the opponent wins. Shooting is not easy though, just by having the cross hairs on the enemy isin’t enough to to register a shot as there’s no aim assist in this game or an aim button that would make your crosshairs any tighter. The first shot will always be to the center, the next ones will go up. You don’t have mid body cover (in third person view at least), making the camper to expose himself entirely and give the rusher a fair fight that never feels unfair. These mechanics are unique to socom, you won't find another third person shooter like this in the market.

You got bullet drop as well. The camera works like it should for most part, even though it still needs some tweaking. In some corners the camera goes into the model head instead of the top of the head, blocking the player vision. The lean feature seems useless at first, but its definitely a good implementation as it helps you with camera angles as well, but totally useless as a cover system. Getting from prone to standing is slow and sluggish, not always being the best option when in a gun fight.

The netcode is really good even on high pings. There’s some other bugs like you can’t crouch while reloading, but those are minor things already being taken care of and are not game breaking enough to be mentioned.

Graphics: - Overall it’s a pretty looking game. Game is still not optimize and you can expect a 10 to 20 fps increase in the future. Some graphical glitches here and there but nothing game breaking. No SLI support for now and I don’t know if they ever will.

Maps: - Only two for the moment. Close to perfect and feel updated to today’s standards. I really think the team made a right move here. You get everything you need when it comes too good map design. A good sense were the enemy is rushing, power points, hard to get spots, nade spots to every camping corner, and the usual “left right and mid” route is simple enough to new players. Not being able to use mid body cover just feels right. Whoever is doing these maps really knows what is doing. Thank god they did the right call in not getting this talent wasted in copy/paste work of the old maps (even if they could) and an actual evolution with new updated and tested techniques. Map editor is being consider so that everyone can enjoy despise their personal taste on this matter.

Game modes: - Team death match and demolition. Its would be nice to see more team objective modes, as it makes some equipment being put to use like smoke grenades. Without voice chat and visuals on the objectives, everything’s casual for now. Since there’s no stats online, ppl are mature and friendly for the most part and will not stress you out for not playing properly. Most people pick their servers by number of players not by game type, you will find yourself playing whatever on low ping.

Sound: - Guns sound really good, but overall it still needs a ton of work yet. There’s sound whoring in this game. If a player is moving the sound whoring is generous enough for him to be heard across an entire building. The music is just ok, some piano tunes you will turn it off after an hour. There’s no voice chat and only way you have to communicate with your team is by text chat. Without voice chat the team play is not there yet.

Servers: - Fast dedicated servers, server list, ping values, recently played players list working. What else could you ask for?

Overall this is a really fun game above all. But as it is you will just play this game in short bursts. Old socom fans know what they want and what they want is something really good, special and unique. We could either see the rise of a really solid game or the fall of an underrated one. Only time will tell.

H-Hour is advertising itself as the spiritual successor of SOCOM 1 & 2. If you were a fan of SOCOM, then an actual real SOCOM game has been on your wishlist for quite some time. While this game is far from finished and a little rough around the edges, it has a solid SOCOM foundation and can only get better from here. Currently, the game only has two maps and two game modes with more maps/modes planned in the future. The guns work well enough but certainly need more tuning to make each gun unique.

This game does provide you with a SOCOM feel; more than any other game to come out over the past decade. It is unfinished but the development team is taking into account peoples suggestions, complaints, and wish lists. If you have been waiting to play SOCOM, then support this game!

I will recommend this game because it needs to succeed.   I won't review based on bugs such as flopped grenades, or no VOIP, because those are staples that will be fixed.

My major concern is, and has been since I got into the beta (especially after the dev Q&A), is bullet velocity.  The game will not be truly competitive unless near instant bullet velocity (if not hit scan).  Having to lead people is not revolutionary, doesn't make it more realistic, creates too much guesswork, and speeds up the general gameplay which is no bueno from a tactical standpoint.  Strafing to dodge their aim isn't how you win in this game, aiming to the middle of someone's strafe pattern is.  If this issue were fixed the gameplay will improve 100%.   Let's hope they do.

All that being said, buy this game so we can get more devs hired to fix this stuff.

H-Hour Early Access review:
Prepare for the long awaited return of a gaming legacy.  Today’s First Person Shooters (FPS) games have catered to the individual.  Where teamwork is unnecessary and experience points has been allowed to set the tone of the game objective.
H-Hour brings something not necessarily new, but fresh to the gaming scene.  SOF Studios revives the Sony Socom legacy from the ashes with this “no respawn” tactical shooter.  This game is not for the casual “Lone Wolf” gamer, but the experienced mature gamer.  You will find no respawn, a minimap showing only teammates, no kill cam; and all by design and demand from those who are hungry for the next challenge in their evolving game play.
H-Hour World’s Elite takes your experience to a whole new level where the actions made by you or a team-member can quickly become the deciding factor of win or lose.  This game will train you through trial by fire to learn how to move more tactically, coordinate with team members to pull off objective goals and bring you a clutching experience that will have you almost as excited spectating your teammates as when your boots are on the ground.
Fight alongside up to 7 additional team mates across intimate maps that provide a “tactical” environment.  Play in one of two game modes (more to come) to accomplish your objective of eliminating the opposing radical force by any means necessary.  With only one life to live each round, you’ll be forced to abandon your solo “run and gun” ways.  You’ll find a complete new way to take the battlefield, and then you’ll find that success will only come from teamwork.  YOLO!
Traverse arenas that have the look and feel like they were stolen right from Google Maps ™!  Use the terrain and structures to give yourself and edge in flanking, stalking and hunting your objective.   You can still take on your opponents in hair raising firefights, but you’ll find your round short lived most like.  Better to join the ranks of the smart players and dominate as a coordinated unit.
This game has been exhilarating from alpha, to beta, and now SOF Studios presents this Early Access edition for the general public.  It is important to note that the game is undergoing extreme development and is far from its final state.  Many might point to this as a down-side.  I beg to differ; I feel that for the game to be this enjoyable at this stage; with many more improvements and content to come…  This game is a solid investment now to get in on the action.
You don’t have to be a veteran of the Socom series (pre Socom 4) to become captured by the addiction.
Disclaimer: In-game microphone communication have now been enabled, but still require more work due to UE VOIP limitations.  Game offers a text chat to work with players without mics, or when mics aren't sufficient.
Early Access is by no indication of the final game product.  This game is still under development, but is stable for game play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

--UPDATE 5/20/2016--

As of yesterday mics now work in game and hit detection has been improved.

TL:DR -
For $10 it is 100% worth a buy if you can cope with a game in development. Don't miss out on getting in  before this game blows up. Join the SOF Studio forums as well because your voice WILL be heard.


Overview-
At its heart H-Hour: Worlds Elite's tries to capture that true competitive third person multiplayer experience that so many of us became so fond of back in the days of PlayStation 2. H-Hour does capture that experience more than any other game I have played over the past  years. This however does not come without its flaws. H-Hour is in Steam Early Access and for that reason one must look over some of these flaws as well... the game is in early access. So let's get into the good, the bad, and the ugly shall we.


The good -
H-Hour captures those moments when you are the last person alive, your palms are sweating and you know your whole team is counting on you. More to this point is that you are severely punished for the mistakes you make. The game forces you to THINK, to outsmart you opponent, after all there is no respawn so when you are dead you have to sit out the entire round.
H-Hour is VERY team oriented (this has come cons with it that I will get into later) and communication is the key. A few amazing players on your team will not win you the match. Rater a less skilled team that has good communication can win even the most one sided maps.

There are NO weapon unlocks! Yes that right you don't get rewarded for playing countless hours by unlocking more powerful guns and  crazy kill steaks. Rater you are rewarded by learning the correct way to play the game given the present circumstance. EVERYONE is on an equal playing field from day one... then again some people have been playing for some time and will mow you down. this just makes you want to play more and get better.

Steam Workshop has been implemented! The community is full of talented individuals making maps for the community to download for free. Many of these maps are remakes of the classics that we all fell in love with over 10 years ago. More maps are coming put every week and make up for the few maps that are currently released with the base game.

The Studio, despite what many will say, is VERY transparent. Sure they keep tight lipped about a lot of stuff but at the end of the day I have never seen a studio so willing to divulge information. Not only that the LISTEN to the community. There have been countless times where the community concerns have completely shifted the dev process (moving to hit scan, workshop implementation, to name a few)


The Bad -
Communication in H-Hour is a MUST. Unfortunately at its current state in development the in-game voice chat is subpar. Currently the player base is using a program called discord to chat with each other and it makes up for the lack of in game voice chat but is still an extra step to take.

User Created rooms need work. We need to be able to set up our own playlists to facilitate with competitive play. I think that this would bring in and retain alot of players.

The learning curve is steep. Although all players have the same guns and stats the game is NOT easy to pick up and just be good at. This is a partial pro in my mind but many will see it as a con. You will have to lose a lot of rounds before getting you first kill but getting that kill is what gets you hooked. That is what gets you addicted. So stick with it if you get discouraged.
Ballistic models need some tuning. This is a very broad subject and it is safe to say that the studio knows that there needs to be more tuning done on guns and grenades.

There is also a low player base. The game is fun but EVERYONE likes to play in a full 8v8 room. this leads to people sitting in the main lobby waiting for a room to fill up. There have been countless occasions where I have just jumped into that empty room and it has filled up in minutes. People are wanting to play they are not willing to be a lone wolf. If this changes I think we would see numbers increase dramatically.



The UGLY-
The hate. plain and simple the hate that this game receives is the most ugly part of the game. People hate on it to just be the cool kid in high school. This impacts every facet of the game. It directly impacts the way the potential investors look at the game. Many of these Haters" will say that they have no interest in the game but will troll on the forums just to cause a stir. When people start putting out positive videos on YouTube about how they are enjoying the game the haters will post negative information.

IT IS IMPORTANT TO NOTE that 90% of these people trying to destroy the game don't play the game.

All of this hate starts to tear at our close knit community from time to time and its sad.



Overall:

This game is on its way to being the game that has been promised to us. It is not there yet and I will be the first to admit that it needs work. BUT the game IS fun! I have meet some amazing people along the way
date: people that I would consider friends and no game has given me that feeling since SOCOM II. If you want to join the fun the community will welcome you with open arms. We are all very passionate about making this game succeed. For $10 you can't go wrong!!"

==Months Later==

The game is finally at a point where it's playable and I actually enjoy playing. I held true to my promise of revising my review. Hopefully the studio will hold true to their promise of making a game for the community.

*Edit*

==Buyer Beware==
Just so you guys know, the studio behind this project, SoF Studios. Has publicly told it's community (on a twitch stream under the official handle) to downvote the negative reviews. You should really think twice before you purchase this.

==Back to the Review==


I played each SOCOM with the exception of SOCOM 4, with 1000+ hours on a few of them. I have been waiting for the day we had a successor to SOCOM come to either the PC / PS4, and when I saw H-Hour I was so excited to see that David Sears was behind the project. However part way through the project David Sears bailed to go to another game development studio, and this game went from being developed on UE3 to UE4.

This is when the wheels fell off.

The major issue with this game is you have a gaming studio who isn't interactive / responsive at all to their community. You have a forum moderating team who censors / bans any users who don't have an extremely positive response to the game.

So here are my positives and negatives.

Positives:
-A community who has ATTEMPTED to guide the development team as to where we want the game.
-A third person shooter.
-User created rooms / lobbys.


Negatives:

-Guns need more tuning as this is a military shooter. **BIGGEST ISSUE** (SOCOM used hitscan with instant bullets where as this game factors in bullet ticks with velocity - They've been told for quite some time to change this to no avail)
-Only 2 maps.
-Only 2 game modes (one of which is VERY early in development)
-No Push to Talk communication system yet
-No minimap
-No bullet indicators
-Cross game text chat between teams (not very tactical)
-Poor interaction between development staff / end users.
-Extremely poor interaction between forum moderating team / end users.
-Extreme censorship of feedback.



3/10 Overall.

(Some of which may be in the process of being implemented)
1. More characters with customization features to help you stand out from everyone else.
2. Bigger arsenal or weapons with customization features to fine tune your playing style.
3. The lean should represent what it did in the older SOCOM games, I shouldn't have to put half of my body outside of the wall to lean properly. That kind of defeats the whole purpose of the lean.
4. The jumping in this game NEEDS to be fixed. It should mimic the older SOCOM games as well.
5. Hit detection is a must, whether or not it's a hit marker or a thud sound when bullets connect.
6. I feel as though the characters are not proportional with the maps. And when your in a gun fight it's almost like your trying to throw a needle at a blade of grass. You have to be VERY accurate in this game or you will suck.

H-Hour World's Elite: By design, this game is the spiritual successor to the original Socoms (1&2). A tactical shooter that relies on teamwork and communication. This game has come a long way and SOF studios is committed to making the best game possible. I have seen that in the process that they have put in place. I can vouch for that this game has recreated that  Socom feeling on more than one occasion. 3 guys left, they have the bomb and it's up to me to stop them. I took out the first two and threw a nade through a window taking out the last one hiding upstairs in the bomb plant site. That was a rush, with palms sweaty and a great sigh of relief when I got the job done.

That Socom feeling isn't something you will get every round for there are so many variables. It's like a big game of chess. Where do I spawn start? What Loadout? Do I rush and possibly give my life to stop their rush tossing grenades? Or do I take a slower approach and try to pick off the enemy and then try to get around them somehow? This game has all of that.. even in it's early state.

If you are a fan of the old games and you want this game to succeed, be a part of the Early Access and make H-Hour, a game that isn't like every other shooter out there.

Check out my full video review of H-Hour Early Access below, complete with gameplay.

UPDATE 2/4/2016: I can no longer recommend this title. It's been HALF A YEAR since my initial review and pretty much nothing has changed aside from a new map and map tools given to the community. The progress on this title is just way, WAY too slow. I'm fairly certain the game will be dead soon and the devs will move on to something else chalking this up as a first attempt at making games that failed.

I wanted to give this a fair shake, and you can see my original review below but i just can't tell people this is worth taking a chance on when i no longer believe this game is going anywhere but up in flames. It's over. It started off as a great idea with a great lead who jumped ship and left the title to rot. Nothing more to see here.



This is a tough one for me. I was one of those guys who backed H-Hour from the start. I've poured dozens and dozens of hours into making videos on youtube to both spread awareness and keep the community connected. I feel this game was released on EA too soon. I've voiced that opinion several times and it got me nowhere fast. But the real question is do i feel like this game is worth your money?

It depends on several factors.

1. Are you a Socom fan from back in the day?
2. Are you willing to risk $15 on a potential failure?
3. Do you care about the personal politics a studio sets forth or community relations?
4. Are you willing to accept that early access is a rough, ugly, and often long process on steam?

For me personally, at this point i think it's worth the buy in price. Personal feelings aside for SOF studios... and trust me i have a long history with them and it's mostly bad. But i have to give them credit from dropping the price down to a decent rate, I still believe it should have been that price to begin with and would have saved them A LOT of frustration but i digress...

I have some faith in Kevin and Russ to pull this off, i really think we need to see more maps and a map editing tool for the community so we can recreate our favorite Socom maps and build new ones. I think this is DIRE, and NEEDS to happen soon. I fear for the future of H-Hour, some bad decisions have been made. But i have had some fun with it over the free weekend and i do plan on making a purchase. I recommend the game to those of you willing to risk it, and i recommend it for those of you who view Socom 1-3 as the greatest online era ever created. For the every day casual steam user? Wait and see how it goes.

This is a spiritual successor to Socom 1 and 2. The game feels like old Socom and is pretty addicting.

I highly recommend the game but if you cannot enjoy the EA development process than I would say wait and see when it is done. It is frustrating waiting for content and updates but that is what EA is, they're still building the game.

The studio has made changes based off of the community feedback and if they continue to do so I feel it will be a great game.

The core of the game is there. They still need to add a lot of features and more maps but it's coming along. From the progress they've made since EA release I feel this game is going to turn out very nicely.

If you ever enjoyed Socom than you should definitely pick the game up.

If you have never played Socom I'd say to get the game but be patient and take the time to learn the game. It is very rewarding.

It's not like most shooters today. There is no auto aim, no perks, all the guns are even across the board and it takes some skill to learn and get good. The guns feel nice and you can have some great gun fights that last longer than .0003 seconds. At the same time you can pick someone off with a headshot.

Can be played however you like. Planning and teamwork is key. You can be stealth and camp or Rambo the other team. Depends on the map, the objective and your skills. It is a fast paced arcade shooter when you're up close but if you hold back can be slower paced and stealthy.

Really awesome game play and looking forward to more content.

25 bucks.

25 bucks.

25 bucks.

Did I mention they want 25 bucks?

For any SOCOM fanatic, like myself, this is a game to keep an eye on. The goal from the kickstarter (originally proposed by David Sears(S1/S2 creator) who is NOT on the team anymore) was to create a true Socom 2 spiritual successor. In many ways they are on track, but in many ways they aren’t. They are still pondering stupid ideas like “Lets put a 50cal in the middle of the map for players to pick up.” Anyone that plays ANY form of competitive game, understands this is a death sentence for eSports. Anything that will create any form of balance issue at any point in the map is game breaking.

******My big gripes. (in no particular order)
--The gun mechanics are ♥♥♥♥. They literally copy/pasted every gun recoil, stats, damage, to every other gun.
--There is no form of voice chat in the game.
--There is no way to tell where your getting shot from. Yes there are sounds, but the game NEEDS the red arrows that SOCOM had.
--Bullet delay ruins any form of gun fighting in the game.
--No animations like, at all. The characters run default UE4, they jump by just floating up in the air.
--The game just feels like it has crap physics. There is no sense of inertia and there is no sense of control over your character.
--Many others, however they will be addressed as this is EA and I will give them the benefit of the doubt.

If you loved SOCOM, keep an eye on this game and revisit it in 2-3 months. If you did not play SOCOM and/or never heard of it because maybe I’m just getting old, then revisit this in 5 months.

But as of right now, 25 dollars is just out of the question for me to even come close to recommending this. I was a supporter of the game in beta, and I still am. But I care more about the people. And I would be screwing the people to say “Hey go buy this game” when there are so many other things you could buy for 25 bucks. This game is an Alpha stage shooter that deserves NO MORE than 10$ of your money in its current state.

I want this game to succeed. And if they get their crap together, I will revise my review as things get patched and corrected. If the game makes it there, I will even rewrite a recommended review. But untill them I bid you all farewell.

Do not expect anything more than a third person perspective that allows you to run, crouch, jump and fire your weapon in the games two maps (yes two), one of which is a poorly designed open linear level. While advertising itself as a tactical shooter the game plays nothing like the series it is trying to imitate. Gun mechanics are horrible and teamwork is impossible due to the game not including voice chat among other basic and simple features. Overall this is as basic as a shooter gets and gives you no reason to play again after your first game is completed. While the one life round based structure is there, each round turns into a boring and bland team deathmatch. Technically the game offers horrible animations, awful sound quality, muddy visuals, numerous bugs and lacks heavily in content. Call it early access but I have been a day one public alpha tester and the progress made has been abysmal.

I do not trust SOFs to ever improve upon the game that is for sale today. Avoid a purchase at all costs until the developer proves they have the intentions and capabilities of delivering the product that was originally promised and begins to treat its paying customers like a professional studio would. As of today there is hardly any game here and what it does is beyond unimpressive. This has been such a massive letdown as a SOCOM fan to write this review. I am also disappointed there are delusional members of the community who are shilling themselves falsely hyping this up just in hopes of the project being saved by mass sales. As a steam user I am disgusted that another game and studio in such poor condition was let into the early access" program. How a two map multiplayer only shooter with zero features was approved is beyond me."

This game seems like it has a promising future. It needs COUNTLESS tweaks to be compared to the mighty Socom 2 (Or even the lesser game socom 3 / CA). It is still in alpha so these tweaks are to be expected.

Should you buy it ?

YES AND NO: This will depends on what you want and your level of patience.

-No because its not actually fun playing a game that is supposed to be a close resemblance of another game but currently FARRR form it. While playing this work in progress you will be consiantly comparing it to the great game its trying to be that already exists. That really ruins the experience.

-YES because you will be supporting the possibility of this game being GREAT and a true subsistute to Socom 2.

In short; Its a gamble.

Either spend the money and have 1/10 of the fun you thought you would have playing it...
OR
Spend the money and play a little but KNOW in the back of your mind you are investing in the future possibility of the developers achieveing what they say rather than the current gameplay of the game.

Personal note:

Playing this game for the 8+ hours on steam made be miss the old game to the point where I acrually broke out my Playstation 2, Socom 2 and download Xlink Kai using the very simple tutorials they offer to get myself up and running.

Playing Socom 2 over xlink kai is the ultimate experience. (And free if you still have your system/game) If you are using a HDTV you can purchase better component cables to make the game look that much better.

Socom2 has a 720 x 480 option so it looks good on a HDTV.

Also , if you are using a monitor you can buy a hdmi adapter for your PS2.

SUMMARY:

If you are looking for that Socom 2 fix, just play the actual game like the true die hard fans.

Simplicity is the key to brilliance"

Early Access Review

In its current Early Access state the game is simply a shell of a full game.  It gives the players an idea of what the graphics will roughly look like in the final product and allows you to shoot some people along the way.

From what I understand, they had this game nearly completed with many more features and animations to the point of being a fairly finished game, but it was using the Unreal 3 Engine.  Now they are in the process of taking what they had on the Unreal 3 Engine and converting it to the Unreal 4 Engine, which isn't as simple as copy pasting.  So this is the current state of the game we are able to play, the beginning of this conversion.  So there are currently a lot of features not yet in the game that were in the Unreal 3 Engine version of the game, they took a slight step back to take a bigger step forward.  But it will take more time, clearly.

The game may not currently be worth the money for the gameplay in the current state, but I would argue that if you are a socom fan, it's worth the money for the support and funding so they can get the job done, because you can easily see and feel that even in this shell of a game, socom is in there, it has huge potential if it reaches its final state.

Early Access Review

A sincere and total disappointment.

I've been following this game since when it was started under different management years ago. Suffice to say I was excited for the release of a socom tribute game.

Fort Five Dollars later of support, a management shift, and then being permitted access to the beta later, I'm hardly inclined to say it was worth it. This game shouldn't be anywhere near early access release in its current, laughable state of a game release. I was willing to be patient when communication between the community and player base was as crystal clear as it was some time ago. Now? I can certainly say the mask of controversy, lack of complete 'hook' in the current state of the game, and the overall lack of a community I feel as attached to in comparison to when H-Hour was still in the making and the website forums were rife with activity, life, and excitement, I can say that I've uninstalled the game. I'm not looking to reinstall the game.

My experience with this game is a regretful one.

EDIT*
Since my aforementioned review was, upon actual personal review, was lacking in true commentary on why the game is actually so lackluster, I'll divulge a little more into it for people to understand.

Game Mechanics:
1) The in game Menu is a total joke. You'd think that's one of the first things you get right when making a multiplayer game, but, I'm not a game dev.
2) Hit Detection and Gunplay: Obviously this is a beta and all of what you see is still in development. However in the state that the means of actually shooting people to accomplish the goals in the game, it's in a state that at the open beta's initial beginning, was a laughing joke of an unplayable state. When I played the day prior to writing this review? I had a feeling of that it hadn't really improved. This to me is evidence the game should have remained in a private Alpha stage a lot longer.
3) Character Animation: Still feels clunky. But, again, Beta. This is in an acceptable state for the time being.
4) Server Balance: There hasn't been a single instance of where I've found a means of the game balancing players on teams. It's all been done with the players. Of whom I've found to really not to enjoy the concept of fair play, and in some cases, I've found servers running where one side simply is stacked with players and they just play the objective and absolutely wreck anyone who pops on the opposing team. This escapes my understanding, but, I'm sure someone can inform me/you the reader.
5) The Player Base: I must say that I'm not too terribly impressed with what I have experienced. Besides the real fallout of the community, I don't really have many positive and memorable experiences with a good portion of people that play the beta currently. Nor, on the forums, do I feel the same sense of community, eagerness, and tenacity as it was pre-management shift. All in all, after really thinking on it, it's not something I wanted to be a part of.

In conclusion: This game really should have stayed in the closed Alpha stage a lot longer. There should have been considerably more development time. I really felt that there was a lack of clarency between the Developers and Playerbase on multiple occasions. All in all, at this stage in the game' development and the state the community is in, I simply cannot recommend it.
